<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 379, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 176, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 258]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 156, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 648]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 730, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 88]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 133, 561, 151]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 165, 240, 182]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 194, 384, 212]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 212, 581, 247]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 271, 228, 287]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 289, 752, 330]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 344, 495, 380]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 410, 384, 427]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 432, 536, 465]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 488, 336, 505]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[247, 508, 428, 580]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 610, 594, 628]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 643, 156, 660]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 670, 583, 721]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \sec^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 766, 242, 783]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 791, 593, 826]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 826, 594, 846]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 852, 556, 881]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 435, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = |\mathrm{f}(x)|\), where \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) is a cubic polynomial. Find the two possible expressions for \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) in terms of linear factors with integer coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 453, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 74, 144, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 74, 606, 92]]<|/det|>
Given that \(256^{x + y} \times 16^{-2x} = 8^{-x + 3y}\), show that \(y = 3x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 74, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 144, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 320, 712, 339]]<|/det|>
Hence find the exact solutions of the following simultaneous equations.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[400, 349, 598, 370]]<|/det|>
\[256^{x + y}\times 16^{-2x} = 8^{-x + 3y}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 380, 566, 400]]<|/det|>
\[x^{2} + 3y^{2} = 56\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 400, 920, 418]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 445, 920, 481]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the graph of \(\mathrm{f}(x) = a\cos bx + c\) , where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants. Given that \(\mathrm{f}(x)\) has a period of \(960^{\circ}\), find the values of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 460, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 94, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 722, 109]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\int_{0}^{2a + 1}\frac{8}{4x + 3}\mathrm{d}x = \ln 16,\) find the exact value of the constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 520, 96, 540]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 515, 144, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 514, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
In the expansion of \((1 + kx)^{15}\), where \(k\) is a constant, the coefficient of \(x^{3}\) is \(- 29 120\). Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 532, 920, 551]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 708, 146, 727]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 701, 670, 732]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(y\) in the expansion of \(\left(8y^{2} - \frac{1}{2y}\right)^{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 708, 920, 727]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 819, 95]]<|/det|>
The polynomial p is such that \(\mathrm{p}(x) = ax^{3} + 11x^{2} + bx + c\) , where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 92, 326, 110]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{p}'(0) = 12\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 107, 435, 126]]<|/det|>
It is also given that \(x + 3\) is a factor of p.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 123, 489, 141]]<|/det|>
When p is divided by \(x - 1\) the remainder is 16.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 154, 344, 172]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 154, 918, 172]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
When \(\mathrm{e}^{5y}\) is plotted against \(x^{3}\), a straight line passing through the points \((- 2.56, 4.38)\) and \((6.54, 9.84)\) is obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 122, 146, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 121, 316, 140]]<|/det|>
Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 918, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 636, 146, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 636, 484, 653]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(x\) for which \(y\) can exist.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 636, 918, 653]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 831, 102]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{f}^{\prime \prime}(x) = (3x + 5)^{-\frac{2}{3}}, \mathrm{f}^{\prime}(1) = 6,\) and \(\mathrm{f}(1) = 20,\) find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}(x).\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 556, 104]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(y = \frac{\mathrm{e}^{-3x + 2}}{x + 1}\) where \(x < -1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 144, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 120, 744, 153]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x} = \frac{\mathrm{e}^{-3x + 2}}{(x + 1)^2} (Ax + B)\) where \(A\) and \(B\) are integers to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 541, 144, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 540, 920, 561]]<|/det|>
Hence show that there is only one stationary point on the curve and find its exact coordinates. [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The 3rd and 8th terms of a geometric progression are 6 and 1458 respectively. Find the common ratio and the first term of this progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 146, 517]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms of a second geometric progression are \(\cos \theta\) , \(2\cos^2\theta\) , \(4\cos^3\theta\) , where \(- 90^\circ < \theta < 90^\circ\) . Find the values of \(\theta\) for which this geometric progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 528, 920, 546]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 102, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 87, 920, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 459, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = 4 + 2\sin 3x\) and the straight line \(AB\). The points \(A\) and \(B\) lie on the curve. The \(x\)-coordinate of \(A\) is \(\frac{\pi}{18}\) and the \(x\)-coordinate of \(B\) is \(\frac{\pi}{3}\) . Find the area of the shaded region, giving your answer in exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 920, 517]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 452, 89]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 11.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 776, 92]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(3 \sin (2\phi + 1.5) = 2\) for \(0 < \phi < 5\), where \(\phi\) is in radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
